comment_text:
This is why "science" should never be taught to school kid with no background in physics, chemistry math skills and critical thinking skills

The whole basis of this piece of video propaganda is based upon a naive misunderstanding of mechanics. Even if the average ocean temperatures were rising (this has never been established) such thermal expansion, even if we fancifully accepted their premise has no chance whatsoever of encroaching on shore lines.

Are the authors even dimly aware of this? If not they are incompetent, and if they are, then they are abusing children with fear mongering based solely on evil intent.

While water, including sea water does indeed increase in volume during some phases of positive temperature change, in some cases the opposite occurs. Science for kids is typically filled with such half truth and political propaganda.

For the record, warming and cooling water does indeed change volume but it does not change mass. The implications of this simple truth mean that thermal expansion in confined containers, open at the top, can not expand outwards but only upwards as in the case of their heated pot.

Guess what, this is exactly the same situation as with the oceans where the "top" is the open atmosphere and "the sides" are the rest of the ocean itself with equal mass with which to contain and confine the presumably heated area.

This means that no matter what the temperatures of adjacent waters their mass and the pressure of their mass will always confine the thermal expansion/contraction on only the vertical axis of sea waters as their temperatures vary. No lateral (sideways) movement of sea waters can be correctly attributed to thermal expansion/contraction.

In "real" science we refer to this as "column height," such as in the expansion of mercury within a thermometer.

In order to determine the amount of thermal expansion/contraction we multiply the column height by the fluids thermal variable coefficient of expansion.

The column height at the shore is effectively zero, if you wade out to your knees, much warmer waters may expand by the width of a knee high column by a hair (less than 1mm) but would this be a huge alarm?

Of course if the upper several hundred meters of deep ocean waters were actually to warm (again only for argument sake) by even as much as a degree, it might actually cause the several hundred uppermost meters of the ocean to rise by a centimetre or two (1 cm is about the length of a fingernail) How does this cause alarm ?

Do you think a ships captain would sound the alarm if the 2.5 miles of water (average depth of the deep sea) under his hull were to rise by a fingernail's width?

Waters below the uppermost several hundred meters are constant in temperature and not subject to change in terms of periods of less than can be measured in thousands of years


You are being misled by your educators, when you begin to learn this you will begin to truly become educated.

Water's actually really weird, because most things shrink when they freeze, not expand. Ice's crystalline structure just ends up taking up more space per molecule than when it's liquid water. Yes. But it has to do with rates of thermal expansion. For example, we use mercury instead of water in (older) thermometers because it expands more as temperature increases, thus allowing for smaller, manageable thermometers. The ground will expand, but not nearly as much as the water. However, I am curious to see the math on this one. Water evaporates all the time. Molecules at the surface have nothing to crash into, so they just carry on going. The hotter it gets, the faster it evaporates because the molecules are more energetic. Air moving over the surface carries away molecules, and with them the energy that they would have put back into the water if they hadn't been blown away. As a result, the temperature drops slightly, which is how sweating makes us cooler. Clouds are the water that has evaporated, and so is rain.

Water expands when it freezes due to crystallization. Normally when fluids solidify they become more compact because the molecules move less. Water is an exception to this as when water solidifies, the H2O molecules form crystalline structures with a lot of space between the molecules. 

As an analogy to this, think of a box of lego pieces that aren't joined together. When you build giant structures, the volume that the lego pieces takes up increases. This is because you built a structure.

When the temperature of liquid water rises, the volume increases, and the other way around. But when liquid water solidifies to ice, the volume increases, although the temperature gets lower. That is caused by the crystal structure of ice where the distances between molecules are larger than in liquid water.

For those saying that ice melting would be the opposite effect, if the ice is present on land (on mountains or w/e) it'll melt and raise the sea level, same for with the ice in the sea. If the ice is only partially submerged, only the submerged part will count as "added volume". The part above the water has no influence on the overall volume of the ocean. However when this ice melts, it may have like 10% Less density, but the amount of ice (now water) which influences it is a lot more.

The ice melting will act as a sort of counterweight, lowering the sea level by melting, while the rest of the water increases in volume when it heats up. All of those people who tell you that the water level's rising because of melting ice are just uninformed.

Ok true that the water expands, but doesn't the land expand as well?

Unfortunately for us, evaporation is proportional to the surface area of the water. As volume increases, surface area grows at a slower rate than the radius (or how we would perceive it - height). In the ideal case of a sphere, volume grows in relation to the radius cubed, where as surface area grows in relation to the radius squared. Therefore, as surface area is only proportional to the cube root of the volume squared.
Right, however colder liquid water will be less voluminous than warmer liquid water. That is the thermal expansion being commented on here. Not the phase transition.

Erm...this thermal expansion argument doesn't really apply to water.  The bonding found in liquid water is actually considerably more condensed than the crystalline structures found in ice.  Therefore, when heating ice, it actually becomes MORE condensed and confined than it was in ice form.  To me, this video is a  little misleading...
No. You're not accounting for the increase in evaporation of the water which will prevent the overall volume from drastically increasing simply as a result of thermal expansion.

silly youtube!

It is certainly not worth destroying the worlds economy to attempt to affect change on the global climate when no measurable negative outcome can be defined from inaction in even the most pessimistic scenarios.

(Part 2 of 2)
- Sea level change can be calculated by applying the calculated volumetric change to the current global ocean surface area.  (for ease of calculation assume a universal vertical sea shore for the largest calculated rise in sea level)

The resulting change in sea level from this calculation of thermal expansion added to changes due to melting ice accumulated of hundreds of years still measures in the fraction of inches.

In other words inconsequential!

(Part 1 of 2)
Statement of the obvious without any conclusion.

- Thermal expansion is real.
- Average ocean temperature changes.
- The change of the average ocean temperature can be measured to some degree of accuracy.
- Using this generalized measurement of sea water temperature math can be used to apply known thermal expansion properties of sea water to calculate volumetric changes. (even accounting for various pressures at the different ocean depths)

That's kind of the point. Using a 2 liter bottle of air instead of water turns it into an observable phenomenon.  But the physics is the same.

What you described is thermal expansion of air. It doesn't tell us anything about the water. In fact, this effect is much smaller in liquids. Using your example, consider a 2 liter bottle filled with liquid inside initially at room temperature. You then put it in fridge to cool it down. Will you observe any contraction? No. It's there, but it's too tiny for us to notice.

You can test this theory by recreating it's opposite reaction.  Take any 2 liter pop bottle and fill it with hot water, then pour out the water and put the cap back on.  The air inside, being warm, will cool and as it does so it will contract which will cause the pop bottle to suck in at the sides.

Same principle in reverse.

Everything gets slightly bigger when the relative heat rises. That's why you put a glass jar with a metal top under warm water to open it easier. It's not because it's boiling, but just because it has more heat energy and thus the molecules are more likely to "jiggle" farther away from other molecules.
